DOC.HEAD: Noriega Would Raise CIA Connection At Drug Trial
EDS: SUBS 4th graf pvs bgng: ``At the same'' to clarify that officials don't expect any of the charges to be scuttled by secrecy issues
DOC.TEXT: Manuel Antonio Noriega's longstanding relationship with the CIA could pose problems for federal prosecutors if the deposed Panamanian strongman is caught and brought to trial on U.S. drug trafficking charges, government sources say. Federal prosecutors expect Noriega would try to force the government to drop charges against him by seeking court disclosure of classified information that he was an informant for the spy agency, these officials added. Such an approach would mirror the legal defense strategy used by Oliver North and others with some success in the Iran-Contra affair, in which independent counsel Lawrence E. Walsh was forced to drop some key charges when the government refused to allow disclosure of secrets in open court. At the same time, Justice Department officials said Thursday they do not expect the secrecy problems in Noriega's case to scuttle any of the charges that the Panamanian helped Colombian drug lords smuggle cocaine and marijuana through Panama to this country. Noriega was indicted in 1988 by grand juries in Miami and Tampa, Fla. Prosecutors are anticipating that Noriega will claim that his alleged drug activities were sanctioned by the U.S. government because he was a CIA informant. But the government is prepared to offer evidence that none of the drug-trafficking activity was approved by the U.S. government, said one source, speaking on condition of anonymity. Prosecutors will argue that just because Noriega may have been an informant for the CIA or the Drug Enforcement Administration he is not immune from criminal prosecution, the source said. The secrecy issues involving Noriega's case were among the items discussed at a meeting about the case Dec. 15 attended by prosecutors, top officials of the Justice Department's criminal division and other law enforcement agents, said spokesman David Runkel. Officials decided at that meeting to try Noriega first on charges filed in Miami that he took a $4.6 million bribe from Colombia's Medellin cartel to protect cocaine-smuggling and money-laundering operations in Panama. Runkel said last week's meeting had been scheduled for several weeks and was not convened in anticipation of the U.S. invasion of Panama. The secrecy problems in Noriega's case were termed ``manageable'' by one official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. But the official quickly conceded that Iran-Contra prosecutors probably thought the same thing about their case against former White House aide North. Walsh was forced to drop major charges that North conspired to divert U.S.-Iran arms sale proceeds to the Nicaraguan rebels, because the government wouldn't release information deemed relevant to the defense. The Classified Information Procedures Act empowers judges to dismiss criminal charges if the government refuses to allow the disclosure of secrets needed for a trial. North was convicted of charges that he tried to cover up his involvement in the Iran-Contra affair. But all Iran-Contra charges against a former CIA agent, Joseph Fernandez, were dismissed recently when the Bush administration blocked disclosure of classified information. In Noriega's case, ``there is certainly going to be a CIPA problem,'' said Victoria Toensing, a former senior Justice Department official who now practices law in Washington. ``When people are saying he was on the CIA payroll, then you are going to have the more complicated level that some of these things regarding sources and methods are classified,'' she said. Before Noriega was indicted in 1988, prosecutors consulted with the CIA and other intelligence agencies, said a government source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The agencies posed no objections to proceeding with the case, the source said. Between the Miami and Tampa cases, Noriega is charged with pocketing some $10 million in bribes and commissions for protecting money-laundering and smuggling operations in Panama. Runkel said the Justice Department decided that Noriega would be tried first on the charges in Miami because prosecutors there have a stronger case. If convicted of all the charges against him, Noriega faces a possible sentence of 145 years in prison and more than $1.1 million in fines.
